article.Heading: Budget 2017: Government pegs FY18 fiscal deficit aim at 3.2% of GDP
article.Summary: Jaitley, however, spelled out the fixed deficit target for 2017-18, but introduced a new framework specifying a fiscal deficit “range” from 2018-19 onwards.
article.Body:
Moneycontrol Bureau

The government on Wednesday pegged the fiscal deficit target at 3.2 percent of GDP for the financial year 2017-18, ensuring adherence to the path of fiscal consolidation, without compromising on public investment.

"...I have pegged the fiscal deficit for 2017-18 at 3.2% of GDP and remain committed to achieve 3% in the following year," Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said.

Fiscal deficit a measure of how much the government borrows in a year to meet part of its spending needs.

The revenue deficit of 2.3% in budgeted estimated 2016-17 stands reduced to 2.1 percent in the revised estimates, Jaitley said.

"The Revenue Deficit for next year is pegged at 1.9 percent, against 2 percent mandated by the FRBM Act," he said.

Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) review committee, headed by former Revenue Secretary NK Singh, last month, has recommended 3 percent fiscal deficit for the next three years, keeping in mind the sustainable debt target and need for public investment.

The committee has also provided for ‘escape clauses’, for deviations upto 0.5% of GDP, from the stipulated fiscal deficit target.

The government today also said that its fiscal policy continues to be guided by the principle of a gradual reduction of deficit and needs to maintain "tight fiscal plan".

"However, any fiscal straight jacketing to meet the FRBM target would not be advisable," the government said.

A push through higher public spending is has been indentified as crucial for providing an impetus to economic growth.

"The government has, therefore, consciously decided to shift the FRBM target of achieving fiscal deficit at 3 percent of GDP, by another year to 2018-19. The estimate of fiscal deficit at 3.2 percent of GDP in 2017-18 shows a correction of 0.3 percent over estimates of 2016-17," the government said.
